title: 114_s2337
content: The Act titled "Visa Waiver Program Security Enhancement Act" requires a visa for aliens who recently traveled to Iraq, Syria, or certain other destinations. The Visa Waiver Program Security Enhancement Act amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to require a visa for nationals of program countries who have traveled to Iraq or Syria in the past 5 years. The Secretary of Homeland Security can also restrict travel for nationals who have visited countries with designated foreign terrorist activities. The Visa Waiver Program Security Enhancement Act allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to restrict travel to the United States for nationals who have visited countries with designated foreign terrorist activities. Electronic passports are required for the Visa Waiver Program. The amendment requires the use of electronic passports with biometric and document authentication identifiers for the Visa Waiver Program countries. The government certifies that it issues machine-readable, electronic passports to its citizens, complying with specific requirements. The amendments will take effect 90 days after the enactment of the Act. The certification requirement under the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act of 2002 is modified to include the use of technology standards for alien applicants. Any alien applying for admission under the Visa Waiver Program must present a passport that meets specific technology standards. SEC. 4. Information sharing and cooperation among Visa Waiver Program countries. The text chunk discusses the required information sharing agreements for countries in the Visa Waiver Program, including the implementation of agreements and compliance with federal air marshal agreements. The text chunk discusses the compliance of countries in the Visa Waiver Program with US aviation and airport security standards, as well as the amendment of information sharing agreements. The amendment (1187(c)(5)) allows for termination of a program country if it fails to fully implement information sharing agreements within 90 days of determination by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, may redesignate a country as a program country once compliance is met with the requirements. Additionally, the time frame for providing advance passenger information is amended to be no later than 1 hour before arrival. The Department of Homeland Security shall consider a country's capacity to identify dangerous individuals when designating or maintaining a country as a program country under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security will assess a country's ability to collect, analyze, and share data on dangerous individuals to determine if it should remain a program country under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security will assess a country's ability to collect, analyze, and share data on dangerous individuals to determine if it should remain a program country under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The assessment includes screening traveler passports against INTERPOL's database and sharing information on lost or stolen travel documents. The government of a country will be evaluated on its collection, analysis, and sharing of biometric and other information about individuals seeking asylum or refugee status, as well as sharing intelligence on foreign fighters with the United States. The government's evaluation will include sharing intelligence on foreign fighters with the United States and multilateral organizations like INTERPOL and EUROPOL. Additionally, there is an amendment to the Act regarding reporting stolen passports promptly. SEC. 5. BIOMETRIC SUBMISSION BEFORE ENTRY. The Secretary of Homeland Security must ensure that aliens traveling to the US under the Electronic System for Travel Authorization submit biometric information before boarding. This includes photographs and fingerprints. The implementation of this requirement will be prioritized in Visa Waiver Program countries with significant importance. The Secretary of Homeland Security will implement biometric requirements for aliens traveling to the US under the Electronic System for Travel Authorization, prioritizing Visa Waiver Program countries with nationals linked to ISIL. The effective date for these requirements will be within 1 year of the enactment of the Act, with possible extensions for up to 24 months if deemed necessary for national security. Additionally, biometric information must be included within 5 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Homeland Security will ensure that biometric information, including photographs and fingerprints, is submitted for individuals traveling to the US under the Visa Waiver Program. Compliance with these requirements can be achieved by signing an agreement to collect and share biometric information with the US. The Secretary of Homeland Security will compare biometric information on a traveler's passport before boarding a conveyance to the US. They will also report any potential threats to the Department of Homeland Security before boarding. The Visa Waiver Program Administration is outlined in Section 6. Section 217(h)(3)(B) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to ensure recovery of the full costs of providing and administering the System and implementing improvements to the Visa Waiver Program. Amounts collected will be credited to the Travel Promotion Fund. Amounts collected under the Trade Promotion Act of 2009 shall be transferred to the Treasury's general fund to cover costs of administering the System and improvements to the Visa Waiver Program. The fees collected for implementing improvements can only be used for that purpose.
